util.properties
Class PropertiesHandler

java.lang.Object
  util.properties.PropertiesHandler

public class PropertiesHandler
extends java.lang.Object

A middleman that loads parsed property values into an object, or stores the values of the object into a .properties file format.

Works with the Property, PropertyGetter, and PropertySetter annotations to manipulate an object's fields or invoke getter/setter methods based on a Properties object with the applyProperties(java.util.Properties) method, as well as as output properties based on the values of the object's fields and results of its getter methods with the extractProperties() method.

Quick Guide:
  • Simple Example
  • Special Types
    • Arrays, Sets, and Lists
    • Everything Else

Simple Example

Account.java: 

 class Account {
     @Property
     public Integer id;
     
     @Property
     public String name;
     ...
 }

someAccount.properties: 

 # A contrived example of a .properties file
 id=24
 name=Douglas Adams

Somewhere in your code: 

 ...
 
 Account someAccount = new Account();
 
 ...
 
 PropertiesHandler propHandler = new PropertiesHandler(someAccount);
 InputStream propStream = this.getContextClassLoader()
                              .getResourceAsStream("someAccount.properties");

 Properties someAccountProperties = new Properties();
 someAccountProperties.load(propStream);
 
 propHandler.applyProperties(someAccountProperties);
 
 System.out.println(someAccount.id); // output: "24"
 System.out.println(someAccount.name); // output: "Douglas Adams"
 
 someAccount.id = 42;
 
 someAccountProperties = propHandler.extractProperties();
 
 someAccountProperties.store(
     new FileWriter("someAccount.properties"),
     "An updated contrived example of a .properties file"
 );
 ...

Updated someAccount.properties: 

 # ... TimeStamp ...
 # An updated contrived example of a .properties file
 id=42
 name=Douglas Adams

Special Types

Arrays, Lists, and Sets

Properties that map to Java arrays, Lists, and Sets of a limited number of types are supported.

    Supported array types:
  • String
  • Boolean
  • Byte
  • Short
  • Integer
  • Long
  • Float
  • Double

Nested arrays, Lists and Sets, are not supported.

Example: 

        #                           v------notice the whitespace----v
        exampleArray=green eggs,ham, bacon # {"green eggs", "ham", " bacon"}
        # .properties string --^           # parsed array --^

Everything Else

It is generally not recommended that you map any Properties to types other than those listed in getSupportedTypes().

Instead, simply write custom getters and setters and apply the PropertyGetter and PropertySetter methods to map custom or complex data to properties.

Other object types can however be fully supported if they satisfy two conditions:

  • Can be cast from a String
  • Has a sufficient toString implementation

Author:
Louis Acresti
See Also:
Property, PropertyGetter, PropertySetter

Method Detail

getObject

public java.lang.Object getObject()
Returns:
the object this PropertiesHandler is reading and/or manipulating

getSupportedTypes

public static java.util.Set<java.lang.reflect.Type> getSupportedTypes()

If you have a property of a type that is not in this list, you may need to specify your own getter and setter that return and accept a *String* value, respectively. It is *possible* for a type not included in this list to work if it has a toString method that returns a string which will generate an equivalent object when casting said string to the type in question.

In other words: 

 MyType object = new MyType();
 if((MyType)(object.toString()) == object) {
     System.out.println("Compatible (maybe)!");
 } else {
     System.out.println("Incompatible (definitely)!");
 }

Returns:
a set containing all of the officially-supported types that can be mapped as a property using PropertiesHandler

applyProperties

public void applyProperties(java.util.Properties loadedProperties)
                     throws PropertyMissingException,
                            PropertyParserException,
                            PropertyInvocationTargetException
Given a pre-loaded Properties object, set fields and/or call setters on our associated property-using object.

Parameters:
loadedProperties - a pre-loaded properties object that will populate fields or call getters/setters on the object this PropertiesHandler is associated with.
Throws:
PropertyMissingException - if a required property is not set in loadedProperties
PropertyParserException - if there are any problems parsing a value from loadedProperties
PropertyInvocationTargetException - if any exceptions occur while invoking a setter method
See Also:
Property, PropertyGetter, PropertySetter

extractProperties

public java.util.Properties extractProperties()
                                       throws java.io.IOException,
                                              PropertyInvocationTargetException
Store all property data associated with our object based on their actual values in the object.

Returns:
a Properties object based on the properties
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if there are any issues writing the data
PropertyInvocationTargetException - if any exceptions occur while invoking a getter method
See Also:
Property, PropertyGetter, PropertySetter
